title: 109_hr5938
content: The Act may be cited as the "Stop Obesity in Schools Act of 2006". The Congress finds that a significant percentage of American adults and children are overweight or obese, with a notable increase in obesity rates among children over the past two decades. Overweight young people are at risk for various health issues, including heart disease, bone and joint problems, sleep apnea, and psychological problems. According to the Department of Health and Human Services, obesity-related illnesses cost the nation $117 billion per year, including $61 billion in direct medical costs and $56 billion in indirect costs. A report by Trust for America's Health found that the US lacks a coordinated national strategy to address the obesity crisis. The US lacks a coordinated national strategy to address the obesity crisis. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in collaboration with various stakeholders, will develop a national strategy to reduce childhood obesity in the United States by 10% by 2010. The strategy will address short- and long-term solutions, outline effective partnerships with different entities, and include measures to overcome obstacles. The national strategy to reduce childhood obesity in the United States by 10% by 2010 will include measures to identify and overcome obstacles. Grants will be provided to local educational agencies for wellness policies and anti-obesity initiatives. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will provide grants to local educational agencies to reduce childhood obesity through wellness policies and anti-obesity initiatives, including improving food nutrition, incorporating nutrition education, increasing physical activity, and other measures determined by the Director to improve health. The Director will provide grants to local educational agencies to reduce childhood obesity. Agencies must agree to cost sharing and submit an application for the grant. They also need to submit an annual accountability report on progress in reducing childhood obesity. Authorization of Appropriations: $20,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2007 to 2010 to reduce childhood obesity. Evaluation of programs for preventing obesity in children and adolescents is mandated by Section 5. The Director is required to evaluate existing programs aimed at preventing obesity in children and adolescents to determine their effectiveness, factors contributing to their success, and feasibility of replication in other locations. A report on the evaluation results must be submitted to Congress within 18 months of the Act's enactment. Authorization of $5,000,000 for fiscal years 2007-2010 to implement evaluation results on obesity prevention programs. SEC. 6. HEALTHY LIVING AND WELLNESS COORDINATING COUNCILS. The Director will provide grants to reduce childhood obesity by establishing healthy living councils and supporting regional workshops. Recipients must use the funds to expand council activities and organize workshops for educators and healthcare providers. The text chunk discusses the establishment of healthy living and wellness coordinating councils to reduce obesity in schools. These councils are composed of educators, administrators, health care providers, and other relevant parties. Entities receiving grants must agree to cover at least 25% of the costs from non-Federal sources. The text chunk outlines the requirements for entities receiving grants under this section, including submitting an annual accountability report on progress in promoting healthy living and reducing obesity in schools. Additionally, it authorizes $10,000,000 for fiscal years 2007 through 2010 to support these efforts. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. The term "Director" refers to the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The term "local educational agency" is defined as in section 9101 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965.
